awd_titl_txt: Nansen and Amundsen Basins Observational System (NABOS) 2023 Mooring Design and Cruise Support
awd_abstract_narration:
The Nansen and Amundsen Basins Observational System (NABOS) is a multidisciplinary observational program that includes physical and chemical oceanographic, atmospheric, and ice observations, complemented by servicing of moorings and deployments of drifting buoys to assess the ocean's role in climate change. These observations are critical to the Arctic Ocean observational network. The NABOS project’s goal is to understand the role of the eastern Eurasian Basin, including its shelves, in redistributing ice and the bulk of Arctic riverine waters between the eastern and western Arctic. Monitoring of the partitioning of freshwater in the eastern Eurasian Basin allows researchers to study the role of different atmospheric regimes in distributing freshwater to different parts of the basins and further downstream to the central Arctic Ocean. The current project will support the recovery of nine existing moorings  and the design, fabrication, shipping, and deployment of nine new moorings to support an additional period of time-series observations. 

The Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution’s (WHOI) Mooring Operations and Engineering (MOE) group will provide expertise and technical services to accomplish the design and fabrication of nine (9) deep-water, under-ice, subsurface moorings for use by the Nansen and Amundsen Basins Observation System (NABOS) Project. These moorings will be deployed in the Arctic Ocean during a cruise that will take place in the late summer of 2023. This award will facilitate the mobilization of nine moorings onto the designated vessel at the departure port. The moorings will be available for rapid deployment during a cruise to the Eastern Eurasian Basins of the Arctic Ocean. The mooring locations provide an east-west array of observations designed to better understand the role of fresh waters in regulating vertical ocean mixing across and along this region and the transport of heat from the ocean interior towards areas of sea ice in the Eurasian and Makarov basins and the northern Laptev and East Siberian seas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this project were to design and fabricate nine under ice instrumented moorings to support physical and chemical oceanographic instrumentation. The moorings were designed to be deployed and recovered in Arctic ice-covered regions. WHOI also lead the at sea operations for mooring deployments and recoveries. The work was performed from the USCGC icebreaker vessel Healy.

The majority of mooring components were shipped to Seattle and loaded on the Healy. The newly procured instrumentation was shipped to Kodiak, Alaska were the NABOS science party would join the Healy. The Healy departed Kodiak on August 26th, the vessel arrived at the first NABOS mooring site (M9) on September 3rd. For the next 17 days, the NABOS mooring array were recovered and redeployed with new instrumentation. The Healy departed the work area on September 21st, the vessel arrived in Tromso on October 1st.

Unfortunately, the NABOS mooring M2 was not able to be recovered. Despite many attempts we could not communicate acoustically with the two acoustic releases on the mooring or the CAT Pinger just below the upper flotation. An extensive acoustic survey over a large area was conducted to try to locate the mooring, no acoustic replies from the releases or Pinger were detected. The new mooring was deployed at the previous M2 site.

 


Last Modified: 09/25/2024
Modified by: John N Kemp
